meanings.def: a piece of jewellery that you wear on your finger, consisting of a round band of gold, silver, etc., sometimes decorated with precious stones
examples: a gold ring
a diamond ring (= a ring with a diamond on it)
He was wearing a ring on his middle finger.
Her mother gave her a beautiful ring.
He slipped the ring on her finger.
I pulled the small ring box out of my pocket.
They exchange rings and wedding vows.
She kissed the great ring of the archbishop of Chicago.
He has earned three Super Bowl rings in the last four years.

meanings.def: an object in the shape of a circle with a large hole in the middle
examples: a key ring
curtain rings
the rings of Saturn
The villagers were literally surrounded by a ring of fire.
a plate of onion rings
His right ear sported a gold ring.
He can blow smoke rings.

meanings.def: a round mark or shape
examples: She had dark rings around her eyes from lack of sleep.
The children sat on the floor in a ring.
The army formed a protective ring around the presidential palace.
The children formed a ring around their teacher.
The street plan of the city has evolved as a series of concentric rings.
He had dark rings around his eyes.
She drew a neat blue ring around the phone number.

meanings.def: an area in which animals or people perform or compete, with seats around the outside for the audience
examples: a boxing ring
a circus ring
The next competitor rode into the ring.
He entered the ring wearing his usual outfit.
He was back in the ring only a month after the injury.

meanings.def: a small flat place on a cooker that is heated by gas or electricity and is used for cooking on
examples: to turn off the gas ring
I put the saucepan on the ring.

meanings.def: a group of people who are working together, especially in secret or illegally
examples: a spy ring
a drugs ring
The four men are accused of running a drug smuggling ring.
Customs officials have broken up a major drug ring.

meanings.def: the opportunity to be successful; success that you have worked hard to get
examples: The girls' outdoor track team has grabbed the brass ring seven times.

meanings.def: to be much better at doing something than somebody else
examples: I used to beat my son at chess but now he runs rings around me.

meanings.def: to announce officially that you are going to compete in an election, a competition, etc.

idioms.def: the opportunity to be successful; success that you have worked hard to get
examples: The girls' outdoor track team has grabbed the brass ring seven times.

idioms.def: to be much better at doing something than somebody else
examples: I used to beat my son at chess but now he runs rings around me.

idioms.idiom: throw your hat into the ring
idioms.def: to announce officially that you are going to compete in an election, a competition, etc.

meanings.def: to surround somebody/something
examples: Thousands of demonstrators ringed the building.
The basin was ringed with specks of dirt and hair.
The village is ringed with beautiful forests.

meanings.def: to put a metal ring around a bird’s leg so that it can be easily identified in the future
to draw a circle around something
examples: Ring the correct answer in pencil.

meanings.def: to phone somebody/something
examples: ring somebody/something up I'll ring you up later.
He rang up the police station.
ring somebody/something When is the best time to ring New York?
I'll ring you later.
Concerned residents can write or ring my office.
ring (up) David rang up while you were out.
He said he was ringing from London.
I'm ringing about your advertisement in the paper.
She rang to say she'd be late.
ring for something Could you ring for a cab?
We rang for an ambulance and he was taken to hospital.
Were there any phone calls for me?
How do I make a local call?
I’ll give you a call tonight.
I’ll give you a ring tonight.

meanings.def: to make a sound because somebody is trying to phone you
examples: Will you answer the telephone if it rings?
The phone rang and rang (= rang for a long time) until eventually someone answered.
I'm just waiting for the phone to ring.

meanings.def: if you ring a bell or if a bell rings, it produces a sound
examples: ring (something) Someone was ringing the doorbell.
The church bells rang.
The doorbell rang loudly.
ring for somebody/something Just ring for the nurse (= attract the nurse's attention by ringing a bell) if you need her.
She climbed out of bed and rang for her maid.

meanings.def: to be full of a sound; to fill a place with sound
examples: The house rang with children's laughter.
Applause rang through the hall.

meanings.def: to be full of a particular quality
examples: His words rang with pride.

meanings.def: to be uncomfortable and be unable to hear clearly, usually because you have heard a loud noise, etc.
examples: The music was so loud it made my ears ring.

meanings.def: if you say that alarm bells are ringing, you mean that people are starting to feel worried and to suspect that something is wrong
examples: The government’s proposal has set alarm bells ringing for people on low incomes.

meanings.def: to sound familiar to you, as though you have heard it before
examples: His name rings a bell but I can't think where we met.

meanings.def: to make changes to something in order to have greater variety
examples: Ring the changes with a new colour.

meanings.def: to make you feel that you can still hear something
examples: His warning was still ringing in my ears.

meanings.def: to ring many times, with one phone call after another
examples: The phone has been ringing off the hook with offers of help.

meanings.def: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true
examples: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.
His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

idioms.def: if you say that alarm bells are ringing, you mean that people are starting to feel worried and to suspect that something is wrong
examples: The government’s proposal has set alarm bells ringing for people on low incomes.

idioms.def: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true
examples: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.

His promise rang hollow.

meanings.def: the sound that a bell makes; the act of ringing a bell
examples: There was a ring at the door.
He gave a couple of loud rings on the doorbell.

meanings.def: a loud, clear sound
examples: the ring of horse’s hooves on the cobblestones

meanings.def: a particular quality that words, sounds, etc. have
examples: His explanation has a ring of truth about it.
Her protestation of innocence had a hollow ring to it (= did not sound sincere).
The story had a familiar ring to it (= as if I had heard it before).
